eksClusterVersionEol.^description: EKS version end of life: {$COUNT} of your clusters are close to end of life. Please proceed to upgrade your cluster.
eksClusterVersionEol.shortDesc: EKS cluster version end of life

eksClusterVersionUpdate.^description: EKS new version: Newer version are available for {$COUNT} of your clusters. Please proceed to upgrade your cluster.

eksEndpointPublicAccess.^description: EKS public endpoint: {$COUNT} of your clusters have enabled public access for endpoint. Disable public access to minimize the security risks.

eksSecretsEncryption.^description: EKS secrets encryption: {$COUNT} of your clusters have disabled secrets encryption. Enable secrets encryption to protect your secrets in your clusters.

eksClusterLogging.^description: EKS cluster logging: {$COUNT} of your clusters have disabled control plane logging. Enable control plane logging for better monitoring.

eksClusterSGRestriction.^description: EKS cluster security group: {$COUNT} of clusters' security groups have provided permission beyond minimal rules. Grant minimum rules to reduce security risks.
eksClusterSGRestriction.shortDesc: EKS cluster security group minimum rules

eksClusterRoleLeastPrivilege.^description: EKS role: {$COUNT} of clusters' roles have full access to one or more services.Grant only required permission to reduce the security risks.

eksNodeGroupSpotInstanceUsage.^description: {$COUNT} Managed Nodegroup(s) are not using Spot Instance.
eksNodeGroupSpotInstanceUsage.shortDesc: Leverage spot instances for  deeper discount for fault-tolerant workload.

eksCostVisibilityPlugins.^description: {$COUNT} Managed Nodegroup(s) do not have cost visibility plugins installed.
eksCostVisibilityPlugins.shortDesc: Implement tool for cost visibility at granular level (e.g. by namespace)

eksNodegroupsWithoutBottleRocketAMI.^description: {$COUNT} Managed Nodegroup(s) are not using Bottlerocket AMI.
eksNodegroupsWithoutBottleRocketAMI.shortDesc: Use EKS-optimized AMI or  Bottlerocket for host OS. These AMIs reduce the surface of  attack, are light-weight and improve resource utilization of the container  host.

eksCheckAutoScaling.^description: {$COUNT} Pod Autoscaler (Cluster Autoscaler or Karpenter) is not installed in the cluster.
eksCheckAutoScaling.shortDesc: Enable autoscaling of Pods based on metrics (Horizontal Pod Autoscaler) or events (KEDA)

eksAutoMountServiceAccountToken.^description: You have not opt out of automounting service token for your pods.
eksAutoMountServiceAccountToken.shortDesc: Prevent attacker from using API token to communicate with the API Server if the Pod is compromised.

eksPodSecurityStandards.^description: Pod Security Standard is not enforced with 'pod-security.kubernetes.io/enforce' label.
eksPodSecurityStandards.shortDesc: Implement Pod Security Standards and Admissions for all namespaces.

eksNamespaceResourceQuotas.^description: Resource Quota is not configured for all namespaces in {$COUNT} cluster(s).
eksNamespaceResourceQuotas.shortDesc: Limit total resources (e.g. CPU and Memory) that can be requested in a given namespace. Helps to avoid bill shock when overprovisioning pods.

eksAuthenticationMode.^description: EKS authentication mode: {$COUNT} of clusters' have 'EKS API' authentication mode disabled. Use 'EKS API' for authentication mode in access configuration of your cluster.

eksPermissionToAccessCluster.^description: EKS permission error: Service Screener don't have access to your {$COUNT} EKS clusters, some check will be skipped on these clusters, please make sure your user have enough permission.
eksPermissionToAccessCluster.shortDesc: User don't have permission to access EKS clusters

eksImplementedPodDisruptionBudget.^description: EKS Pod Disruption Budget: {$COUNT} of clusters' don't have Pod Disruption Budget. Prevent disruption and increase  availability of workloads by limitting the number of concurrent disruptions to Pods.

eksDefaultDenyIngressNetworkPolicy.^description: EKS Default Deny Ingress: {$COUNT} of clusters' don't have a defaut deny ingress network policy. This policy prevent Pods from communicating with each other unless allowed explicitly.
eksDefaultDenyIngressNetworkPolicy.shortDesc: Create default deny ingress network policy

eksDefinedResourceRequestAndLimit.^description: EKS defined resource request and limit: {$COUNT} of clusters' have containers without resource request and limit defined. This helps kube-scheduler to allocate pods to the right node. Helps Karpenter and Fargate to scale out right-sized nodes.
eksDefinedResourceRequestAndLimit.shortDesc: Defined resource request and limit for container

eksConfigureLimitRange.^description: EKS configure LimitRange: {$COUNT} of clusters' don't have LimitRange defined. This helps to ensure that a single object cannot monopolize all available resources within a namespace. Also enforce default Resource Request and Limit for containers.

eksPodSpread.^description: EKS Pod spread constrant: {$COUNT} of clusters' don't have any Pod Topology Spread Constraints defined. Helps to spread pods across Availability Zones and Hosts. Optional for workload (e.g. data processing) which require Pods to be placed in the same availability zone.

eksLivenessReadiness.^description: EKS Liveness, Readiness, Startup Probes: {$COUNT} of clusters' contain container without Readiness, Liveness, and Startup Probes defined. By default, traffic are sent to containers immediately. Setting these probes allow Kubernetes to know when  your applications are ready to receive traffic or if they have became  unresponsive.
eksLivenessReadiness.shortDesc: Implement Readiness, Liveness, and Startup Probes

eksSecurityContext.^description: EKS security context: {$COUNT} of clusters' contain container without security context. A security context defines privilege and access control setting for a Pod or Container. It prevents attacker from getting too many priviledges if Pod is compromised.
eksSecurityContext.shortDesc: Configure Pods and Containers  Security Context

eksPodIdentityIRSA.^description: EKS Pod Identity IRSA: {$COUNT} of clusters' don't use Pod Identities or IRSA. Applications in a Pod's containers can use an AWS SDK or the AWS CLI to make API requests to AWS services using AWS IAM permissions. EKS Pod Identities and IRSA provide the ability to manage credentials for your applications, similar to the way that Amazon EC2 instance profiles provide credentials to Amazon EC2 instances. Instead of creating and distributing your AWS credentials to the containers or using the Amazon EC2 instance's role, you associate an IAM role with a Kubernetes service account and configure your Pods to use the service account.
eksPodIdentityIRSA.shortDesc: Use EKS Pod Identities or IRSA

eksUpdateInsights.^description: EKS Update Insights: {$COUNT} of clusters' have ERROR and/or WARNING update insights. To fix these findings, you need  to update your Kubernetes manifests to stop using deprecated APIs. This helps  to avoid compatibility issues after upgrading your EKS clusters.
eksUpdateInsights.shortDesc: Fix ERROR and WARNING update insights

eksKarpenterConfiguredExpireAfter.^description: EKS Karpenter configure 'disruption.expireAfter': {$COUNT} of clusters' are using default 'disruption.expireAfter' for all NodePool. This feature rehydrates nodes to  ensure that they are upgraded with the latest AMI and dependencies periodically.

eksKarpenterResourceLimit.^description: EKS Karpenter limits: {$COUNT} of clusters' includes NodePool without limits. Set limits for node pools to keep cost in check.

eksKarpenterConfigureConsolidation.^description: EKS Karpenter consolidation: {$COUNT} of clusters' don't have cosolidation policy. Enable this make Karpenter consolidate / terminate under-utilised nodes.

eksKarpenterRestrictedInstanceType.^description: EKS Karpenter limits: {$COUNT} of clusters' includes NodePool with instance type restricted. Ensure that Karpenter nodepools  are not restricted by instance type.
